item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Selective Catalytic Cross‐Cyclotrimerization En Route to1,4‐Diborylated Benzenes and Their Synthetic Transformations
item.dc:description: Abstract A synthesis of 1,4‐diborylated benzenes was achieved by the Ru‐catalyzed regioselective co‐cyclotrimerization of alkynes with a commercially available ethynyl boronate. The reaction is applicable to a wide array of alkynes with metal‐coordinating groups, providing synthetically useful diborylated benzenes in 23–68% isolated yields. DFT calculations shed light on the reaction course and the origin of its remarkable regioselectivity. Selected diborylated benzenes were converted into various products, such as quinones and hydroquinones, including three natural bioactive small molecules.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A synthesis of 1,4-diborylated benzenes was achieved by the Ru-catalyzed regioselective co-cyclotrimerization of alkynes with a commercially available ethynyl boronate. The reaction is applicable to a wide array of alkynes with metal-coordinating groups, providing synthetically useful diborylated benzenes in 23–68% isolated yields. DFT calculations shed light on the reaction course and the origin of its remarkable regioselectivity. Selected diborylated benzenes were converted into various products, such as quinones and hydroquinones, including three natural bioactive small molecules.
item.dc:creator: Alexander A. Fadeev, Gabriele Manca, Martin Kotora
item.dc:title: Selective Catalytic Cross‐Cyclotrimerization En Route to1,4‐Diborylated Benzenes and Their Synthetic Transformations

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Copper‐Catalyzed Olefination of 4‐CF3‐Substituted Cyclohexadienones Using Sulfonylmethyl Isocyanides: An Electrostatic Repulsion‐Controlled Regioselectivity Switch Strategy
item.dc:description: Abstract A Cu(OTf)2‐catalyzed olefination of cyclohexadienones was developed using sulfonylmethyl isocyanides. A CF3 moiety at the 4‐position of cyclohexadienones was shown to exert a pronounced electrostatic repulsion effect to give the olefination products via a preferential [3+2] cycloaddition with the ketone moiety followed by a facile fragmentation of transient oxazoline intermediates. The current Cu(II)‐catalyzed olefination of 4‐CF3‐substituted cyclohexadienones demonstrates the reaction dichotomy involving a CF3‐controlled 1,2‐addition over a Van Leusen 1,4‐addition pathway through the electrostatic repulsion effect.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A Cu(OTf)2-catalyzed olefination of cyclohexadienones was developed using sulfonylmethyl isocyanides. A CF3 moiety at the 4-position of cyclohexadienones was shown to exert a pronounced electrostatic repulsion effect to give the olefination products via a preferential [3+2] cycloaddition with the ketone moiety followed by a facile fragmentation of transient oxazoline intermediates. The current Cu(II)-catalyzed olefination of 4-CF3-substituted cyclohexadienones demonstrates the reaction dichotomy involving a CF3-controlled 1,2-addition over a Van Leusen 1,4-addition pathway through the electrostatic repulsion effect.
item.dc:creator: Seungwon Lee, Mohamed Ahmed Abozeid, Hun Young Kim, Kyungsoo Oh
item.dc:title: Copper‐Catalyzed Olefination of 4‐CF3‐Substituted Cyclohexadienones Using Sulfonylmethyl Isocyanides: An Electrostatic Repulsion‐Controlled Regioselectivity Switch Strategy

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Linear Enamides and Enecarbamates via Photoredox Acceptorless Dehydrogenation
item.dc:description: Abstract In recent years, several methods for the direct desaturation of aliphatic compounds have been developed, facilitated by the unique combination of photoredox and transition‐metal catalysis. Hereby, alkenes with high functionalization potential can be prepared in a straightforward fashion. We adapted a previously reported system involving tetrabutylammonium decatungstate (TBADT) as hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) agent and a cobaloxime co‐catalyst for dihydrogen evolution for the dehydrogenative preparation of linear enamides and enecarbamates from saturated precursors. The substrate scope includes several natural products and drug derivatives. The reaction does not require noble metal catalysts, exhibits short reaction times compared to previous methods and is suitable for the late‐stage functionalization of drug derivatives.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

In recent years, several methods for the direct desaturation of aliphatic compounds have been developed, facilitated by the unique combination of photoredox and transition-metal catalysis. Hereby, alkenes with high functionalization potential can be prepared in a straightforward fashion. We adapted a previously reported system involving tetrabutylammonium decatungstate (TBADT) as hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) agent and a cobaloxime co-catalyst for dihydrogen evolution for the dehydrogenative preparation of linear enamides and enecarbamates from saturated precursors. The substrate scope includes several natural products and drug derivatives. The reaction does not require noble metal catalysts, exhibits short reaction times compared to previous methods and is suitable for the late-stage functionalization of drug derivatives.
item.dc:creator: Ritu, Daniel Kolb, Nidhi Jain, Burkhard König
item.dc:title: Synthesis of Linear Enamides and Enecarbamates via Photoredox Acceptorless Dehydrogenation

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Evolution and Future of Hetero‐ and Hydro‐Trifluoromethylations of Unsaturated C−C Bonds
item.dc:description: Abstract The difunctionalizative trifluoromethylation of unsaturated C−C bonds is a highly useful and efficient method for the synthesis of trifluoromethyl compounds with attractive architectures from simple feedstocks, allowing the introduction of the CF3 group along with a wide variety of substituents either inter‐ or intramolecularly. Given that trifluoromethyl molecules are increasingly used as promising bioactive species in the design of new drugs and agrochemicals, difunctionalizative trifluoromethylation has been extensively studied during the last decade. This review focuses on reactions proceeding via the simultaneous formation of C−heteroatom (O, N, S, Se, B) and C−H bonds, as these reactions provide useful CF3 group‐containing building blocks. To identify the trends and prospects of the evolution of this methodology, we systematically describe the variants of these types of reactions and provide a more general view of reaction conditions, modes, and mechanisms. The presented comprehensive survey enables the categorization of reactions into those that are synthetically mature and those with room for further development.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

The difunctionalizative trifluoromethylation of unsaturated C−C bonds is a highly useful and efficient method for the synthesis of trifluoromethyl compounds with attractive architectures from simple feedstocks, allowing the introduction of the CF3 group along with a wide variety of substituents either inter- or intramolecularly. Given that trifluoromethyl molecules are increasingly used as promising bioactive species in the design of new drugs and agrochemicals, difunctionalizative trifluoromethylation has been extensively studied during the last decade. This review focuses on reactions proceeding via the simultaneous formation of C−heteroatom (O, N, S, Se, B) and C−H bonds, as these reactions provide useful CF3 group-containing building blocks. To identify the trends and prospects of the evolution of this methodology, we systematically describe the variants of these types of reactions and provide a more general view of reaction conditions, modes, and mechanisms. The presented comprehensive survey enables the categorization of reactions into those that are synthetically mature and those with room for further development.
item.dc:creator: Shintaro Kawamura, Pablo Barrio, Santos Fustero, Jorge Escorihuela, Jianlin Han, Vadim A. Soloshonok, Mikiko Sodeoka
item.dc:title: Evolution and Future of Hetero‐ and Hydro‐Trifluoromethylations of Unsaturated C−C Bonds

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Nickel‐Catalyzed Intermolecular Branched/Linear Regioselective C−H Alkylation of 4‐Oxoquinazolines
item.dc:description: Abstract A Ni−NHC‐catalyzed prototype reaction based on the alkylation of C−H activated 4‐oxoquinazolines with aryl and alkyl alkenes was demonstrated. When aryl alkenes are used as the substrates, the regioselection of the reaction can be fine‐tuned by choosing a NHC ligand with appropriate steric hindrance to harvest branched adducts, while the use of a bulky NHC/alkyl aluminum cocatalyst system helps to steer the reaction towards linear products. For alkyl alkene substrates, Ni(cod)2, IMes ⋅ HCl and NaOtBu system can directionally generate linear products, and long‐chain olefins are also applicable. In addition, the catalytic mechanism was also explored through the deuteration experiments, and the migration of nickel was suggested in the catalytic cycle.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A Ni−NHC-catalyzed prototype reaction based on the alkylation of C−H activated 4-oxoquinazolines with aryl and alkyl alkenes was demonstrated. When aryl alkenes are used as the substrates, the regioselection of the reaction can be fine-tuned by choosing a NHC ligand with appropriate steric hindrance to harvest branched adducts, while the use of a bulky NHC/alkyl aluminum cocatalyst system helps to steer the reaction towards linear products. For alkyl alkene substrates, Ni(cod)2, IMes ⋅ HCl and NaOtBu system can directionally generate linear products, and long-chain olefins are also applicable. In addition, the catalytic mechanism was also explored through the deuteration experiments, and the migration of nickel was suggested in the catalytic cycle.
item.dc:creator: Yaqi Zhang, Shengxiang Qin, Bendu Pan, Rihui Cao, Raymond Wai‐Yin Sun, Liqin Qiu
item.dc:title: Nickel‐Catalyzed Intermolecular Branched/Linear Regioselective C−H Alkylation of 4‐Oxoquinazolines

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Stereoselective Three‐Component Construction of Conjugated 1,3‐Dienes via Palladium‐Catalyzed Alkene/Allene/Carbenoid Insertion Cascade
item.dc:description: Abstract A three component construction of conjugated 1,3‐dienes bearing oxindoles or isoquinolinediones from alkenylated aryl iodides, allenes and diazo compounds via a palladium catalyzed sequential alkene/allene/carbenoid insertion reaction was developed. Three C−C bonds were formed in high order, offering access to multi‐substituted dienes in high yields and up to >20:1 E/Z selectivities. The reaction features excellent functional groups tolerance under mild conditions.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A three component construction of conjugated 1,3-dienes bearing oxindoles or isoquinolinediones from alkenylated aryl iodides, allenes and diazo compounds via a palladium catalyzed sequential alkene/allene/carbenoid insertion reaction was developed. Three C−C bonds were formed in high order, offering access to multi-substituted dienes in high yields and up to >20:1 E/Z selectivities. The reaction features excellent functional groups tolerance under mild conditions.
item.dc:creator: Haixia Zhao, Yuchen Jiang, Tongqing Weng, Yongjia Shang, Jian Wang
item.dc:title: Stereoselective Three‐Component Construction of Conjugated 1,3‐Dienes via Palladium‐Catalyzed Alkene/Allene/Carbenoid Insertion Cascade

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Polymer‐Supported Phosphoric‐Acid Catalysed Enantioselective Pictet‐Spengler Cyclisation for the Synthesis of Quaternary Tryptolines in Batch/Continuous Flow
item.dc:description: Abstract The enantioselective Pictet‐Spenlger reaction of tryptamines and diketo compounds catalyzed by a polymer‐supported phosphoric acid (TRIP) has been accomplished for the first time in continuous flow. Using this approach, a diverse library of quaternary tryptolines has been synthesized in 36–95% yield with 39–99% enantiomeric excess. The scalability of the reaction has been demonstrated in continuous flow, with a residence time of only 24 minutes. The robust immobilized catalyst has been recycled and reused multiple times in batch and flow. The synthesis of the chiral precursors of Tadalafil, the Iboga‐type alkaloid (+)‐Tabertinggine and antimalarial spiroindolinones has been achieved in batch and continuous‐flow.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

The enantioselective Pictet-Spenlger reaction of tryptamines and diketo compounds catalyzed by a polymer-supported phosphoric acid (TRIP) has been accomplished for the first time in continuous flow. Using this approach, a diverse library of quaternary tryptolines has been synthesized in 36–95% yield with 39–99% enantiomeric excess. The scalability of the reaction has been demonstrated in continuous flow, with a residence time of only 24 minutes. The robust immobilized catalyst has been recycled and reused multiple times in batch and flow. The synthesis of the chiral precursors of Tadalafil, the Iboga-type alkaloid (+)-Tabertinggine and antimalarial spiroindolinones has been achieved in batch and continuous-flow.
item.dc:creator: Moreshwar B. Chaudhari, Prachi Gupta, Patricia Llanes, Miquel A. Pericàs
item.dc:title: Polymer‐Supported Phosphoric‐Acid Catalysed Enantioselective Pictet‐Spengler Cyclisation for the Synthesis of Quaternary Tryptolines in Batch/Continuous Flow

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Catalytic Radical‐Polar Crossover Non‐Classical Semipinacol Rearrangements: The Sustainable Approach
item.dc:description: Abstract. Semipinacol rearrangement has brought several elegant methods for the rapid synthesis of various complex scaffolds and as a result, has been applied extensively in the total synthesis of natural products. Apart from the classical ways, where transition metal or acids catalyzes the formation of carbocation, the semipinacol rearrangement has seen numerous revolutions and now are being happening in an eco‐friendly manner relying on a catalytic radical‐polar crossover tool. These catalytic processes are mainly occurring through photocatalysis or electrocatalysis. This review will provide a brief idea of these developments. Contents: 1. Introduction 2. Photocatalytic radical‐polar crossover 3. Electrocatalytic radical‐polar crossover 4. Metal‐free radical‐polar crossover 5. Conclusion and Outlook Keywords: electrocatalysis• ketone • photocatalysis• polar‐cross over • radical
item.content:encoded: Abstract. These catalytic processes are mainly occurring through photocatalysis or electrocatalysis. This review will provide a brief idea of these developments. Contents: 1. Introduction 2. item.title: From Peripheral Stereogenic Center to Axial Chirality: Synthesis of 3‐Arylthiophene Atropisomers.
item.dc:description: The front cover picture illustrates the palladium‐catalyzed the chirality transfer from peripheral stereogenic carbon center to axial chirality starting from 8H‐indenothiophen‐8‐ols. The process is different from traditional point‐to‐axial chirality transfer aromatization reaction of a non‐aromatic intermediate, in which the new created chiral axis is usually directly attach to a stereogenic centers. This reaction provides an easy way to access highly functionalized 3‐arylthiophene atropisomers in high enantioselectivity. Details can be found in the Update by Junwei Xi, Zhenhua Gu and co‐workers (L. Li, J. Xi, B. Hong, Z. Gu, Adv. Synth. Catal. 2023, 365, XXXX–XXXX; DOI: 10.1002/adsc.202200957)

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Visible‐Light‐Induced Direct C−H Amination of Quinoxalin‐2(1H)‐ones
item.dc:description: Abstract A visible‐light‐induced direct C(sp2)−H amination of quinoxalin‐2(1H)‐ones toward the synthesis of substituted 3‐aminoquinoxalin‐2(1H)‐ones with TMSN3 has been firstly developed. This transformation achieved C(sp2)−H/N−H coupling in the absence of external ligand and oxidant. Notably, this methodology features mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope and operational simplicity.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A visible-light-induced direct C(sp 2)−H amination of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones toward the synthesis of substituted 3-aminoquinoxalin-2(1H)-ones with TMSN3 has been firstly developed. This transformation achieved C(sp 2)−H/N−H coupling in the absence of external ligand and oxidant. Notably, this methodology features mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope and operational simplicity.
item.dc:creator: Yanpeng Liu, Congcong Pei, Xiaoyu Chen, Jianye Zhang, Jingya Li, Dapeng Zou, Yangjie Wu, Yusheng Wu
item.dc:title: Visible‐Light‐Induced Direct C−H Amination of Quinoxalin‐2(1H)‐ones

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: One‐Pot Construction of Fluorinated Chiral Alcohols via Sequential Substitution/Asymmetric Transfer Hydrogenation of α‐Bromoarylketones and Fluoroalcohols
item.dc:description: Abstract A one‐pot synthesis of fluorinated chiral alcohols from α‐bromoarylketones and fluoroalcohols is described. The fluorinated ketone intermediates were formed from α‐bromoarylketones with fluoroalcohols as nucleophiles and solvents, which were reduced subsequentially by adding a chiral Ru catalyst and a mixture of formic acid and triethyl amines (FA: TEA=1.1:1) as hydrogen donor to give 27 examples of fluorinated chiral alcohols in 60–93% yields and 85–98% ee values. Notably, K3PO4 acts as a base in nucleophilic substitution and an additive in reductive step to enhance the reactivity and enantioselectivity, which is crucial for constructing compatible conditions for one‐pot process. This one‐pot process is also applicable to gram‐scale synthesis.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A one-pot synthesis of fluorinated chiral alcohols from α-bromoarylketones and fluoroalcohols is described. The fluorinated ketone intermediates were formed from α-bromoarylketones with fluoroalcohols as nucleophiles and solvents, which were reduced subsequentially by adding a chiral Ru catalyst and a mixture of formic acid and triethyl amines (FA: TEA=1.1:1) as hydrogen donor to give 27 examples of fluorinated chiral alcohols in 60–93% yields and 85–98% ee values. Notably, K3PO4 acts as a base in nucleophilic substitution and an additive in reductive step to enhance the reactivity and enantioselectivity, which is crucial for constructing compatible conditions for one-pot process. This one-pot process is also applicable to gram-scale synthesis.
item.dc:creator: Rongrong Zhao, Qiao Wei, Yuxin Huang, Qin Qu, Qixing Liu, Haifeng Zhou
item.dc:title: One‐Pot Construction of Fluorinated Chiral Alcohols via Sequential Substitution/Asymmetric Transfer Hydrogenation of α‐Bromoarylketones and Fluoroalcohols

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: β‐Functionalized and α,β‐Difunctionalized Ketones from 1‐Arylallylic Alcohols via Dipotassio α,β‐Dianion Intermediates
item.dc:description: Abstract This study reports the synthesis of diverse β‐functionalized ketones from readily available 1‐arylallylic alcohols in the presence of (trimethylsilyl)methylpotassium (TMSCH2K). The reaction proceeded via the formation of the highly nucleophilic dipotassio α,β‐dianion as the key intermediate, which served as a metal homoenolate equivalent. This protocol also allowed the one‐pot synthesis of α,β‐difunctionalized ketones using two different electrophiles, thus demonstrating its synthetic advantages over other protocols involving metal homoenolates.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

This study reports the synthesis of diverse β-functionalized ketones from readily available 1-arylallylic alcohols in the presence of (trimethylsilyl)methylpotassium (TMSCH2K). The reaction proceeded via the formation of the highly nucleophilic dipotassio α,β-dianion as the key intermediate, which served as a metal homoenolate equivalent. This protocol also allowed the one-pot synthesis of α,β-difunctionalized ketones using two different electrophiles, thus demonstrating its synthetic advantages over other protocols involving metal homoenolates.
item.dc:creator: Rikuo Hayashi, Kaori Ando, Taro Udagawa, Masahiro Sai
item.dc:title: β‐Functionalized and α,β‐Difunctionalized Ketones from 1‐Arylallylic Alcohols via Dipotassio α,β‐Dianion Intermediates

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Cobalt‐Catalyzed Cascade Reaction of Ynamides and 1,3‐Dicarbonyl Compounds To Selectively Construct Different‐Sized N‐Heterocycles
item.dc:description: An efficient triphenylphosphine‐ligated cobalt‐catalyzed cascade cyclization manifold with various 1,3‐dicarbonyl compounds and halogenated N‐Allyl Ynamides was accomplished under alkaline reaction conditions, thus providing an expedient route to valuable different‐sized N‐Heterocycles. This is the first example that demonstrates the selective synthesis of different ring sizes (5‐, 6‐, and 7‐membered rings) N‐heterocycles via cobalt catalysis, and the reaction has broad substrate scope and tolerates a wide range of functional groups.
item.content:encoded: An efficient triphenylphosphine-ligated cobalt-catalyzed cascade cyclization manifold with various 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds and halogenated N-Allyl Ynamides was accomplished under alkaline reaction conditions, thus providing an expedient route to valuable different-sized N-Heterocycles. This is the first example that demonstrates the selective synthesis of different ring sizes (5-, 6-, and 7-membered rings) N-heterocycles via cobalt catalysis, and the reaction has broad substrate scope and tolerates a wide range of functional groups.

item.dc:title: Cobalt‐Catalyzed Cascade Reaction of Ynamides and 1,3‐Dicarbonyl Compounds To Selectively Construct Different‐Sized N‐Heterocycles

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Direct Suzuki‐Miyaura Coupling of Naphthalene‐1,8‐diaminato (dan)‐Substituted Cyclopropylboron Compounds
item.dc:description: Abstract We herein describe the direct Suzuki‐Miyaura coupling of dan‐substituted, saturated organoboron compounds. Despite its Lewis acidity‐diminished character of the boron center, cyclopropyl‐B(dan) can be activated by t‐BuOK to undergo transmetalation with a palladium complex. The increased s‐character of the C−B(dan) bond as compared with other alkyl‐B(dan) should be the key to the reaction.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

We herein describe the direct Suzuki-Miyaura coupling of dan-substituted, saturated organoboron compounds. Despite its Lewis acidity-diminished character of the boron center, cyclopropyl-B(dan) can be activated by t-BuOK to undergo transmetalation with a palladium complex. The increased s-character of the C−B(dan) bond as compared with other alkyl-B(dan) should be the key to the reaction.
item.dc:creator: Mikinao Koishi, Kazuki Tomota, Masaaki Nakamoto, Hiroto Yoshida
item.dc:title: Direct Suzuki‐Miyaura Coupling of Naphthalene‐1,8‐diaminato (dan)‐Substituted Cyclopropylboron Compounds

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: From Peripheral Stereogenic Center to Axial Chirality: Synthesis of 3‐Arylthiophene Atropisomers
item.dc:description: Abstract A practical synthesis of axially chiral biaryls via chirality transfer from peripheral stereogenic carbon centers is reported. In contrast to the traditional aromatization process of a non‐aromatic structure with ipso stereogenic centers, this method is based on a Pd‐catalyzed carbon‐carbon bond cleavage/ring‐opening reaction of optically active 8H‐indenothiophen‐8‐ols with an achiral ligand, enabling synthesis of highly functionalized 3‐arylthiophene atropisomers in high enantioselectivity.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A practical synthesis of axially chiral biaryls via chirality transfer from peripheral stereogenic carbon centers is reported. In contrast to the traditional aromatization process of a non-aromatic structure with ipso stereogenic centers, this method is based on a Pd-catalyzed carbon-carbon bond cleavage/ring-opening reaction of optically active 8H-indenothiophen-8-ols with an achiral ligand, enabling synthesis of highly functionalized 3-arylthiophene atropisomers in high enantioselectivity.
item.dc:creator: Lin Li, Junwei Xi, Biqiong Hong, Zhenhua Gu
item.dc:title: From Peripheral Stereogenic Center to Axial Chirality: Synthesis of 3‐Arylthiophene Atropisomers

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Unexpected Stereoselective Access to 2‐Aminooxazolines from Propargyl Ureas by Silver Salts under Mild Conditions
item.dc:description: Abstract Propargyl ureas can lead to a range of possible heterocyclic compounds, mainly depending on the employed catalyst. Silver salts are known to promote the N‐5‐exo‐dig cyclization mode to imidazolidinone derivatives. Conversely, a versatile and stereoselective O‐5‐exo‐dig cyclization of propargyl ureas to 2‐aminooxazolines by Ag(I) catalysis is here disclosed. Good to excellent yields and complete stereoselectivity of the external double bond have been achieved under milder reaction conditions (50–60 °C). A one‐pot protocol starting from the corresponding propargylic amines and isocyanates has been developed as well. N,N’‐Dipropargyl ureas underwent a uncommon O‐5‐exo‐dig/N‐5‐endo‐dig double cyclization sequence. Finally, insights into the tautomeric equilibrium of 2‐aminooxazoles and on their relative reactivity are provided.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

Propargyl ureas can lead to a range of possible heterocyclic compounds, mainly depending on the employed catalyst. Silver salts are known to promote the N-5-exo-dig cyclization mode to imidazolidinone derivatives. Conversely, a versatile and stereoselective O-5-exo-dig cyclization of propargyl ureas to 2-aminooxazolines by Ag(I) catalysis is here disclosed. Good to excellent yields and complete stereoselectivity of the external double bond have been achieved under milder reaction conditions (50–60 °C). A one-pot protocol starting from the corresponding propargylic amines and isocyanates has been developed as well. N,N’-Dipropargyl ureas underwent a uncommon O-5-exo-dig/N-5-endo-dig double cyclization sequence. Finally, insights into the tautomeric equilibrium of 2-aminooxazoles and on their relative reactivity are provided.
item.dc:creator: Aleksandr Voronov, Alessandra Casnati, Paolo P. Mazzeo, Paolo Pelagatti, Alessia Bacchi, Raffaella Mancuso, Bartolo Gabriele, Elena Motti, Giovanni Maestri, Péter Pál Fehér, András Stirling, Nicola Della Ca'
item.dc:title: Unexpected Stereoselective Access to 2‐Aminooxazolines from Propargyl Ureas by Silver Salts under Mild Conditions
